analytic.title: Découverte d’une église à bêma et de sa mosaïque en Anatolie orientale (Turquie)

biblStruct.note: The church of Gola is one of the few religious buildings with bema located outside the diocese of Antioch. Dated from the end of the 5th or the 6th century ce, it is located in a valley between the Mesopotamian plain and the Upper Tigris. Its architectural features and mosaic pavement testify to the influence of northern Syria, especially the regions of Apamea and Antioch. The main carpet represents the toil of the spring months along with a scene of hunting and animals chasing each other. The mosaic features several Syriac inscriptions, including a dedication that states the date on which the paving was made. The position of the building, at the edge of the Eastern Roman Empire, prompts us to explore the cultural relations of this region with other parts of the empire and to examine its local context, in the cradle of the Syriac world.
